ContextContent.Paragraph: Councils in NSW are independent and locally elected corporate bodies. They levy rates to provide essential services and are also responsible for regulating some developments and land use, enforcing local laws, and providing community services and programs.

The disposal of council records is covered by the General retention and disposal authority: local government records (GA39) which was issued in 2011 and is on the priority list for review. GA39 is the largest current disposal authority with 928 entries.

State Records NSW has been working with councils and Museums of History NSW (MHNSW) to revise and streamline GA39 since 2022. Feedback from councils and MHNSW’s suggestions were incorporated into the exposure drafts and are noted in the justifications.

The revision includes removing entries that are covered appropriately by other disposal authorities and consolidating entries. The number of entries has been reduced from 928 to 99, 30% of which are required as State archives.

Exposure drafts were released in October 2023 and August 2024 to all councils and a focus group meeting was held with councils that provided feedback. Eighteen councils provided feedback and the majority supported the changes and were keen for the new disposal authority to be issued. A small number of councils expressed concerns about resources to implement a new disposal authority. State Records NSW will continue to provide assistance to councils with this process.
In additional to all councils in NSW and MHNSW, State Records NSW consulted with the following organisations:
NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption: Records of corruption or misconduct made against individual councillors. Required as State archives (8.1) Agree with State archives decision
NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption: Did not have any changes to the status of State archives, nor retention periods.
Independent Pricing and Regulatory Tribunal: Reviewed the draft and did not have any comments.

NSW Police Force: Allegations of sexual abuse of children and young people by clients, visitors, service providers, members of the public. Retain for 45 years (5.4) Noted that Police investigations of sexual assault are retained for 99 years. State Records NSW suggest no changes needed as any allegations received by a council will be referred to the appropriate body - NSW Children’s Guardian (reportable conduct notifications are retained for 50 years) and/or the Police (99 years).

NSW Police Force: Management of emergencies that involve loss of life. Retain for 25 years (11.3) Noted that Police retain these for 30 years State Records NSW suggest no change needed as councils forward any records required for an investigation to the Police.
NSW Police Force: Routine management of community services and programs. Retain until administrative and reference use ceases (5.7) No issue with entry
NSW Police Force: Body worn video recordings required as evidence for the investigation. Retain for 7 years (17.2) Noted this is consistent with the NSW Police.

NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS): Hazard prevention and reduction operations and fire bans. Retain for 7 years (11.5) Suggested retention period be increased from 7 to 10 years for consistency with RFS disposal authority. Agreed.

NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) : Routine day-to-day operation of emergency control centres. Retain for 2 years (11.6) Suggested retention period be increased from 2 to 12 years for consistency with RFS disposal authority. State Records NSW suggest no change needed as councils are not the lead agency for bush fires and the 2 year retention period has been in place for many years.

Department of Planning, Housing and Infrastructure (DPHI): Development & building controls (9.0) Provided advice on the operations of the Planning Portal which is used to lodge all development applications in NSW. DPHI clarified that councils should manage the records of applications where they are the consent authority rather than leaving the records in the Portal repository Note has been added to entries 9.2 & 9.3.

Environmental Defenders Office: Sent their thanks for being consulted and advised they would have liked to have contributed, however on account of very limited capacity, they were unable to make a submission.
Audit Office of NSW: Did not have any feedback.
Cyber Security NSW: Reviewed the document and have nil comment on the proposed changes.
NSW Ombudsman: Thanked State Records NSW for seeking their feedback and had no comments.
Office of Local Government: Reviewed the draft and had no comments. Provided advice around management of the companion animal register.

NSW Electoral Commission: Records relating to the preparation for elections (10.4) Requested that the disposal action be changed from 'retain a minimum of 6 months or at the direction of the Electoral Commission' to 'retain in accordance with Local Government Regulation' as the Regulation has specific requirements around these records. Agreed.
The NSW Building Commission, Crown Lands, and the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water did not respond to the request for feedback.
Below is a summary of proposed changes to the existing disposal authority:

All local government records created prior to 1920. Previously required as State archives. The requirement for all local government records created prior to 1920 to be transferred as State archives has been removed.

However, the introduction to the new disposal authority will advise councils to contact State Records NSW for advice if they have records they would like to be considered for transfer as State archives that are not required as State archives elsewhere in the disposal authority. This would apply to records of any date rather than just limiting it to pre-1920. If any approaches are made, State Records NSW will liaise with MHNSW. This requirement in GA39 was based on the premise that pre-1920 records were scarce. The experience of State Records NSW and MHNSW since the disposal authority was issued in 2011 is that there are a number of routine records pre-dating 1920 across the state and this requirement did not allow MHNSW to refuse these records. Examples are routine correspondence, financial records, draft minute books (where final versions existed), works ledgers with no detail of locations etc.
Management of stray animals. Retain for 5 years 2.2 Retention period reduced from 10 to 5 years 5 years is consistent with other animal welfare programs and meets business needs.

Registration of companion animals. Retain until administrative or reference use ceases 2.3 Retention period reduced from 15 years to until administrative or reference use ceases. The register is now managed by the Office of Local Government and will be covered in their disposal authority. The proposal is to retain the register for 99 years (life of the owners to provide evidence of non-compliance with animal welfare laws)
Firearm licences. Retain for 7 years after expiry. 3.2 Increase in retention period from 2 to 7 years 2 years after expiry for a licence to carry firearms was not seen as sufficient.
Management of community services and programs. Retain for 7 years 5.5 Retention period reduced from 10 to 7 years To streamline the authority and 7 years meets business needs.

Declarations and disclosures of pecuniary interest and benefits by councillors. Retain minimum of 10 years after term of office ceases 8.2 Removal of requirement to retain all declarations and disclosures by councillors as State archives if no summary records exist. This requirement is not necessary as entry 8.1 requires summary records of declarations as State archives.

Routine management of councillors. Retain until administrative or reference use ceases. 8.4 Previously most of these records were retained for between 2 and 6 years. This has been changed to retain until administrative or reference use ceases. To streamline the authority

Career summaries of councillors. Retain until administrative or reference use ceases. 8.4 Change from required as State archives to retain until administrative or reference use ceases. Entry 8.1 already requires summary records of disclosures of interests, the dismissal, censure and/or suspension of individual councillors, allegations of fraud, corruption or misconduct made against individual councillors, transcripts of final versions of addresses, speeches or papers delivered by councillors at significant occasions or public events as State archives.

Certificates associated with development applications that are required as State archives 9.2 Change from 10 years after action completed to State archives Advice from councils that certificates should be managed as part of the same record

Models submitted as part of development application. 9.2 Removal of note that architectural models could warrant retention as State archives. During the review MHNSW noted that their experience is models submitted to councils as part of a development application do not warrant retention as State archives.

Certificates associated with development applications that are not required as State archives. Retain for 10 years after structure demolished. 9.3 Change from 10 years after action completed to 10 years after structure is demolished or removed Advice from councils that certificates should be managed as part of the same record

Records relating to the preparation for elections. Retain in accordance with Local Government Regulation. 10.4 Disposal action changed from retain for 6 months or destroy as required by the Electoral Commission to “retain in accordance with Local Government Regulation”. Request from Electoral Commission

Operational records relating to environmental management. Retain for 15 years. 12.3 Retention period reduced from 20 to 15 years for pest and weed control plans, programs and notifications. 15 years meets business needs and consistent with retention period for environmental monitoring. Any use of harmful pesticides by council staff will be required to be retained for 75 years under the General retention and disposal authority: administrative records

Successful applications for grants or funding received or distributed by the organisation. Retain for 7 years after completion of program. 14.3 Applications that lead to new or significant programs no longer required as State archives. Applications are important to retain for a certain period of time for auditing purposes, but the applications do not meet the State archives criteria. Reports on grant programs are required as State archives under entry 5.1.

Monitoring and inspections of businesses, facilities, buildings, water cooling systems, food premises etc. where there are widespread public health and safety or compliance issues. Required as State archives. 17.1 No change to disposal action but scope widened to include widespread compliance issues. Previously this only covered public health issues and there was a gap in reports on major compliance issues in local government, e.g. compliance with building standards.

Permits for road openings, hoardings, gates across public roads, blasting, hairdressing, and licensed food premises. Retain for 7 years 17.3 Retention period reduced from 10 to 7 years To streamline the authority and 7 years meets business needs.
Permits for fireworks and cranes. Retain for 7 years 17.3 Retention period increased from 2 to 7 (cranes) and 5 to 7 (fireworks). Risks involved in cranes and fireworks.
Permits for low risk activities in parks. Retain for 1 year. 17.4 Retention period reduced from 5 to 1 year Low risk activities.

Audio visual surveillance and monitoring records (e.g. CCTV and Body Worn Video) not required for evidentiary purposes. Retain until administrative or reference use ceases 17.5 New entry for gap in coverage. Any recordings that are needed for an investigation will be extracted and retained as per the records of the investigation. These recordings do not record any incidents and take up substantial storage space.

Maintenance programs and maintenance works and repairs of parks, reserves and associated structures and facilities. Retain for 7 years. 19.2 Retention period reduced from 15 to 7 years. Advice from councils that 7 years meets business needs.

Road engineers works or site diaries. Retain for 7 years. 21.6 Changed from required as State archives or life of structure to 7 years. Feedback from councils that information from diaries is summarised elsewhere.

This authority has been benchmarked against:
Western Australia General Retention and Disposal Authority for Local Government Information (2023)
Queensland Local Government Sector Retention and Disposal Schedule (2008)
South Australia Local Councils and Local Governing Bodies and Authorities (2020)
Tasmania Disposal Schedule for functional records of Local Government (2017)
Victoria Retention and Disposal Authority for Records of Local Government Functions (2019).

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities associated with the monitoring and review of local government areas and boundaries, and proposals for the amalgamation or splitting of administrations.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to agreements regarding the transfer of responsibilities and ownership of assets due to administrative change.
for records of policies relating to the management or administration of amalgamations or area or boundary reviews.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to Council input into:
reviews of local government areas and boundaries and the proposed amalgamation, abolition or splitting of administrations
ward boundaries within local government areas.

Records include:
proclamations of the constitution of cities and areas, amalgamations, abolitions and of the naming or re-naming of areas and wards
proposals, recommendations or representations submitted to the Minister, Electoral Commissioner, the Bureau of Statistics, etc.
submissions received
commissioned research or reports
final results of polls or referendums.
Includes amalgamations which do not proceed.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 1 Records document the establishment, structure and functions of local government.
Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania, South Australia and Queensland.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

This entry covers council input into and responses to boundary changes, amalgamations and splitting of administrations. Councils can also propose changes to boundaries outside of this process, and can conduct polls and referendums.

The Local Government Boundaries Commission examines and reports on any matter referred to it by the Minister in relation to the boundaries of local government areas and the areas of operation of county councils. These determinations are required as State archives under the Commission's disposal authority.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records of arrangements and routine correspondence relating to the administration and management of amalgamations, boundary and ward boundary reviews or changes. Includes records relating to arrangements for consultation processes, the placement of public notices of proposals, correspondence etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Tasmania retains for 2 years, Victoria retains until administrative use has concluded.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activity of managing the control, treatment and preservation of domestic animals, livestock and wildlife. Includes the registration of companion animals.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to animal welfare policies.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the development of standards for animal welfare and control of domestic and companion animals or livestock. Includes local standards on the protection of native fauna, intensive animal housing, restrictions on domestic animals in public reserves, animal rescue and rehabilitation.
Records include significant drafts and final versions, background research, etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Basis for determination
Building the Archives Policy: Objective 4 Records contribute to the knowledge or understanding of aspects of the history, society, culture or peoples of NSW.
Benchmark: Consistent with Western Australia and Tasmania for native animals.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.

Justification/Remarks: No change. The Department of Primary Industries and the National Parks and Wildlife Service are also responsible for animal welfare standards but these records will provide evidence of how this was managed at the local level around the state.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the management of programs for animal welfare and services for the control and protection of animals, e.g. rescues, pounds and stables, provided by or on behalf of the organisation. Includes:
management plans
records of searches for owners
collection, impounding, destruction or sale of stray animals
project files, reports, reviews and evaluations of programs and services.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Victoria retains for 7 years. Western Australia retains between 2 and 7 years. South Australia for 6 years. Tasmania for between 2 and 10 years.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011 for programs for animal welfare.

Justification/Remarks: Retention period for records relating to the management of services for the control and protection of animals, e.g. rescue, pounds and stables reduced from 10 to 5 years for consistency with other jurisdictions and to streamline the authority.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the registration and identification of companion animals. Includes:
permanent identification forms and registration forms
change of owner/details forms
microchip verifications
declarations of ownership
companion animal registers.
Note: the Companion Animal Register is now managed by the NSW Government. The register has been included to allow for the disposal of legacy records.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Tasmania retains for 10 years.

Justification/Remarks: Change from 2 years after creation of record for companion animal forms to until administrative or reference use ceases. This was a previous requirement of the Office of Local Government which has now been removed.
Change from 15 years for the Register of Companion Animals to administrative or reference use as the Register is now managed by the Office of Local Government.

Class.LinkedTo: 19.4.4 - changed from 2 years after creation of record to until administrative or reference use ceases. Councils can retain 2 years.
19.8.3 - reduced from 15 years to administrative or reference use. This register is managed by Office of Local Government now

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to service coordination, delivery and daily operations of pounds and other animal welfare services, e.g. work orders and schedules, microchipping services, etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Victoria retains for 1 year, Western Australia and Tasmania for 2 years.
Justification/Remarks: Retention period changed from 2 years to administrative or reference use ceases for routine records. Feedback from some councils that 2 years was not required.

Class.LinkedTo: 11.12.2 - change from 2 years to until administrative or reference use ceases. Councils can retain 2 years

TermDescription.Paragraph: The process of granting permission for the organisation to undertake a requested action. Includes authorisations for staff to carry out regulatory and enforcement activities, deduct money from bank accounts etc.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to permission from the organisation to organisations and individuals to undertake activities.
for records of credit card holder data.
for authorisations given by individuals to the organisation granting permission to take and use images of individuals in publications, on websites and intranets.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records of the design of the Council seal and authorisation for the use of the Council Seal.
Note: the Seal is an object and not a State record, therefore not covered by this disposal authority and not required as State archives.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 1 Records provide evidence of legal delegations to perform duties and functions.
Benchmark: Consistent with Tasmania and Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change.

The seal of a council must be kept by the mayor or the general manager, as the council determines. The seal of a council may be affixed to a document only in the presence of (a) the mayor and the general manager, or (b) at least one councillor (other than the mayor) and the general manager, or (c) the mayor and at least one other councillor, or (d) at least 2 councillors other than the mayor.

Class.LinkedTo: 2.7.1 - no change for design of Council seal

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to licences, authorisations, accreditations, appointments and delegations of authority enabling the organisation and individual staff to carry out activities, e.g. food safety and environmental protection licences, authorities to destroy animals, to enter private property, appointment of local fire control officers etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Western Australia. South Australia retains for 6 years after expiry. Tasmania retains between 2 and 10 years after expiry.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011 for staff to conduct compliance checks.

Justification/Remarks: Retention period changed from between 2 (firearm licensing), 3 (authorisation to act as emergency response officers) and 10 (appointment of emergency services personnel to act as local fire control officers) years to 7 years to streamline the authority. 2 years was not seen as sufficient for licences to carry firearms.

Class.LinkedTo: 9.3.1 - increase from 3 years to 7 years after expiry for authorisations for the organisation's staff to act as emergency response officers
22.2.2 - increase from 2 years to 7 years after expiry for firearm licensing
9.1.1 - decrease from 10 years to 7 for appointment of emergency officers

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the acquisition of an interest in land (an easement) by the organisation to provide facilities and public services, e.g. road widening, parks, etc. Includes negotiations, agreements and extinguishments, and negotiations that are not proceeded with.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Western Australia. Tasmania retains for 3 years after date registered, South Australia for 6 years after expiry.
Justification/Remarks: No change. Records needs to be in place while the easement is required to access property for maintenance etc

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records of authorisations and supporting documents received from residents, ratepayers and users of services. This includes:
documents authorising the deduction or withdrawal of money from accounts, e.g. direct debit authorisations to pay rates, membership fees etc.
documents such as powers of attorney, wills, death certificates provided to manage rates on behalf of another person or a deceased estate.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Western Australia. Tasmania retains for 1 year.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change to authorisations to withdraw money or charge credit cards. Scope expanded to cover powers of attorney etc.

Class.LinkedTo: authorisation - to withdraw money from accounts

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities relating to establishing rapport with, and advocating for, the community. Includes liaison activities, conferral of awards, etc.
Note: see relevant entry in FA450 for responses to enquiries that require a detailed response.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to addresses for training, professional, community relations or sales purposes. Includes speeches and multi-media presentations.

for records relating to arranging and managing festivities, including celebrations, formal ceremonies and social functions, to honour a particular event, occasion or individual, or to conduct fundraising. Includes arrangements for consultation forums.
for records relating to the receipt of awards by the organisation
for records relating to contacts lists.

for records relating to partnerships between the organisation and other organisations where one assists the other in return for a promotional benefit and the management of donations of money, items, artefacts or property to or by the organisation
for records relating to analysing, creating and promoting products and services
for records relating to stablishing a relationship between the media and the organisation.
for records relating to complaints or suggestions that require investigation or a specific response.
for records relating to the concept, design and construction of memorials such as commemorative plaques, statues, clocks, time capsules etc.
Records relating to the development and production of the organisation's corporate style

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the conferral of significant awards, such as Freedom of Entry or Keys to City. Records include successful applications, nominations and certificates.
Note: objects such as Keys to City are not State records and are not covered by the disposal authority.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 4: Records relate to events, persons, places and social, environmental, or cultural phenomena of significance to the broader community and the State of NSW.
Benchmark: Consistent with Tasmania and Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

Class.LinkedTo: 2.3.1 - no change for conferral of significant awards

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Key records of liaison with, and advocacy for, the local community where the organisation commissions research and/or prepares a detailed paper or response. Includes:
input into issues that affect the local community such as immigration, sustainability, State planning proposals etc.
liaison with local associations (chamber of commerce, progress associations), industry, professional and customer associations, the local community, etc. on matters that affect the local area and economy, and matters of major public interest or controversy with regard to waste management.
Records include: requests for comment, summaries of responses, submissions, reports of research etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 5 Records document the impact of government activities on the community.
Benchmark: Consistent with Queensland, South Australia, Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011

Justification/Remarks: No change. These records demonstrate councils responding to issues within their community and also advocating on behalf of the community in areas that are outside their jurisdiction such as welcoming of immigrants to regional areas.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Routine records of community liaison. Includes:
the receipt or conferral of routine awards such as garden prizes, tidy towns, citizenship awards, etc.
liaison with other organisations on behalf of residents or community organisations, e.g. advocacy on behalf of disabled people to provide access to facilities, provision of letters of support to community organisations applying for grants to other organisations, etc.
routine liaison with industry and consumer associations, the local community, etc.
calls for submissions, comments or feedback on particular matters or issues.
Note: Records of submissions and reports on outcomes of community consultation relating to a specific topic should be sentenced according to the relevant function/activity.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Victoria, Western Australia & Tasmania retain for 7 years, 2 years for unsuccessful nominations. South Australia retains for 6 years.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

Class.LinkedTo: 2.5.1 - no change for calls for submissions, comments feedback

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to input into community issues where the organisation submits a minor response or does not take action

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Tasmania retains for 2 years.
Justification/Remarks: Change from 2 years after action completed to until administrative or reference use ceases.

Class.LinkedTo: 2.10.2 - change from 2 years to administrative or reference use
14.11.2 - change from 2 years to administrative or reference use

TermDescription.Paragraph:
The activities of developing and providing community services and programs. Includes:
public health and safety
sister cities
attracting new business, infrastructure, etc. in the area.
community aged care, disability and homeless services
banking services, communications services etc
housing, community transport and other forms of social support
the development of precincts and public spaces, including public art initiatives, such as sculptures, paving, fountains, etc.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to accreditations and licences to operate services, etc
for records relating to environmental management programs.
for records relating to the management of cemeteries and crematoria .
for records relating to the management of galleries, museums, sporting and recreational venues.

SeeReference.AuthorityTitleRef: Provision and regulation of childcare services
SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to the operation of child care, centres, family day care etc
for records relating to campaigns to promote the organisation's services and programs.
for records relating to complaints, letters of appreciation etc
for records relating to the management of commercial activities.
for records relating to agreements with other Government organisations.
for records relating to audits of services provided.
for records relating to reports by staff of cases of alleged child abuse
for copyright declaration forms signed by users.
for records relating to the development of plans and strategies for community services.
for records relating to the treatment and care provided to patients at hospitals, nursing homes or community health centres operated by or on behalf of the organisation.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Key records of community services and programs that are aimed at addressing systemic issues within the local government area, have long term outcomes, or demonstrate innovation. Includes public health, road safety, homelessness, migrant resettlement, sporting, tourism, cultural, recreational, economic development programs, Sister City programs etc.

Records include:
program objectives, reports, submissions, evaluations
agreements and memoranda of understanding
negotiations and liaison with external community services providers
audio visual recordings produced by or on behalf of the organisation for community awareness purposes.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 5 Records document the impact of government activities on the community.
Benchmark: Consistent with Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change.

Class.LinkedTo: 2.11.3 - no change for audio visual programs for community awareness purposes
15.2.1 - no change for reports on significant programs funded by grants received by the organisation

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the establishment, negotiation, maintenance and review of agreements to provide and operate community services such as aged care centres, disability services, meals on wheels etc.

Records include:
correspondence and records of negotiations
final, approved versions and significant drafts of agreements
reviews of agreements.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Benchmark: Consistent with records of agreements in Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania.
Justification/Remarks: No change

Class.LinkedTo: 8.11.1 - changed from 10 years after action completed to 7 years after expiry of agreement for agreements for other agencies to provide services on behalf of Council

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the provision of direct care and/or services to clients of community programs and services, including the aged, people with a disability, the homeless, etc. Records include:
client case files
assessments of eligibility and entitlements
indemnity waivers, disclaimers and authorisations
health assessments
records relating to injuries or accidents involving clients and any treatment provided
complaints concerning care provided or the operations of the service and records of actions taken in response to the complaints.
Note: see FA404 for the provision of childcare services, GDA17 for the provision of health care services and FA402 for sporting and gymnasium programs.

Disposal.DisposalTrigger: client reaches or would have reached 25 years of age
client leaves service or last attended

List.Item: Consistent with WA and Victoria
Consistent with Queensland except for home – based care which is 5 years after discontinuation of service, and respite care for 10 years.
South Australia retains for 6 years after client exits.
Tasmania retains youth programs for 15 years after program completion, aged care for 7 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change.

Records of allegations of involving abuse or neglect of children by a member of staff will be retained for 100 years. Any complaints that relate to a serious breach by the Council will be retained as State archives (see entry 9.1).
The provision of childcare services is covered by a separate disposal authority and minimum retention periods are set by national childcare regulations.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the handling of allegations of sexual abuse of children and young people by clients, visitors, service providers and members of the public that are received by the organisation.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to allegations against members of staff and volunteers.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Meets the recommendation of the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Allegations of Child Sexual Abuse which has been incorporated into all relevant disposal authorities.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011

Justification/Remarks: No change. Allegations against members of staff are covered by the General retention and disposal authority: administrative records PERSONNEL – Misconduct and are retained for 100 years.

Class.LinkedTo: 3.7.3 - records relating to the handling of allegations of sexual abuse placed in separate entry
allegations - sexual abuse of children and young people

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the management of community services and programs provided by, or on behalf of, the organisation. Includes:
reports of activities and inspections
programs of events and activities
management, service and operational plans
requests and applications for services
negotiations or proposals for programs which do not proceed
activities undertaken under Sister City agreements such as visits or economic exchange and gifts
routine liaison with external community services providers
assessment of proposals for economic development.

List.Item: Western Australia retains for 7 years.
Victoria retains for between 2 and 7 years.
Queensland and Tasmania retain for between 5 and 10 years.
South Australia retains for 6 years. or between 5 and 10 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Justification/Remarks: Retention period reduced from 10 to 7 years as this meets business needs.

Class.LinkedTo: 8.11.1 - reduced from 10 years to 7 years for provision of services

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the implementation and coordination of community events, programs and campaigns. Includes:
support for local businesses to attend or hold events such as trade displays
staging of cultural, sporting and recreational events e.g. Australia Day, Seniors Week, NAIDOC week, Christmas, markets etc.
implementing public education and public road safety campaigns
Records include liaison, applications to hold events, schedules, information kits, program outlines, reports from coordinators of community services, traffic management plans etc.

List.Item: Consistent with Western Australia
Victoria retains for between 2 and 7 years.
Queensland and Tasmania retain for between 5 and 10 years.
South Australia retains for 6 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Justification/Remarks: No change.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the routine management of community services and programs:
service co-ordination and daily usage, e.g. client listings, bookings, operation schedules, referrals, service requests, etc.
applications for and renewals of services provided by the organisation, such as applications to place details and advertising in service and visitor centres, applications and renewals for post boxes, etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria, Tasmania and Queensland.
Justification/Remarks: Change from 2 years to administrative or reference use ceases to streamline the authority.

Class.LinkedTo: 8.11.2 - change from 2 years to administrative or reference use ceases

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities associated with complying with mandatory or optional accountability, legal, regulatory or quality standards or requirements to which the organisation is subject. Includes compliance with legislation and with national and international standards.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to breaches of the organisation's laws
for records relating to audits of services operated by the organisation.
for records relating to the organisation’s compliance with mandatory or optional standards or with statutory requirements.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to serious breaches or failures of the organisation to meet compliance requirements. Records include correspondence and reports.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to allegations of fraud, corruption or misconduct made against individual councillors

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 2 Records provide evidence of key failures in the administration of local government in NSW.
Benchmark: Consistent with Western Australia
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to minor breaches or failures to meet compliance requirements.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with South Australia and Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities associated with gatherings held to formulate, discuss, update or resolve matters pertaining to the management of the organisation. Includes arrangements, agenda, taking of minutes, etc.

SeeReference.SeeText: relevant function/activity for records relating to petitions received by councillors.
for records relating to the management of internal, external or inter-agency committees, task forces, working groups or parties, etc
for records relating to routine general and section or unit meetings of employees and senior management diaries

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the meetings of Council and sub-committees of Council. Records include:
agenda, minutes and business papers
advice and briefing papers
submissions and reports
recommendations and resolutions
correspondence arising from business discussed or resolutions passed at meetings.

Note: There is no requirement to create hard copy minutes of Council meetings to comply with the State Records Act. Copies of Council meeting papers, including councillors' copies, may be disposed of under the normal administrative practice (NAP) provisions of the State Records Regulation.
A sub-committee of Council is comprised of Council members only.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 2 Records provide evidence of key decisions influencing the administration of local government in NSW.
Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to preparation for Council meetings and the production of minutes. Records include draft minutes, transcripts and audio visual recordings used to prepare minutes.

Disposal.DisposalTrigger: minutes of meeting have been confirmed

List.Item: Consistent with Tasmania and Queensland.
Victoria retains until administrative use concluded.
South Australia retains until reference use ceases.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to questions without notice and administrative arrangements for meetings. Includes:
audio visual recordings of meetings for the purpose of facilitating public access to Council meetings (e.g. webcasts)
meeting notifications
catering, venue bookings etc
related correspondence
tracking of actions due.
Note: The Office of Local Government’s Model Code of Meeting Practices states the webcasts/recordings of meetings should be retained on the council’s website for at least 12 months.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria and Tasmania. South Australia retains for 2 years. Western Australia for 1 year
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: Retention period for questions without notice changed from 2 years to administrative or reference use to streamline the authority. No change for other records.

Class.LinkedTo: 13.6.3 - change from 2 years to administrative or reference use
council meetings - tracking of actions due

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities associated with managing and supporting councillors.

SeeReference.SeeText: relevant function/activity for records created or received by councillors in an official capacity, in the course of undertaking business on council's behalf or in relation to their role as councillors.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Key records of elected Councillors. Includes:
summary records of disclosures of interests, e.g. pecuniary interests and benefits, voting on planning matters, campaign donations etc.
the dismissal of whole Councils and the appointment of administrators
the dismissal, censure and/or suspension of individual councillors
allegations of fraud, corruption or misconduct made against individual councillors
delegations for members of governing bodies or their sub-committees to enter into agreements or arrangements that bind the organisation, including ministerial delegations.
transcripts of final versions of addresses, speeches or papers delivered by councillors at significant occasions or public events
the design of the chains of office, crest/logo, coat of arms, Mayoral robes, official presentation items and the flag.

Justification.Paragraph: Basis for determination:
Building the archives policy: Objective 2 Records provide evidence of key decisions influencing the administration of local government in NSW.

List.Item: Consistent with Western Australia (except for registers of interest which are retained for 30 years
Consistent with Tasmania
Consistent with Queensland except for minor breaches of code of conduct which are retained for 7 years.
Consistent with South Australia for allegations that are investigated. Allegations not investigated and summary records of declarations of interest are retained for 6 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: no change.

Class.LinkedTo: 2.1.1 - no change for significant speeches delivered by Councillors
codes of conduct, breaches of - Councillors

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records of disclosures, conditions, entitlements, allowances, leave, fees and facilities provided to councillors. Records include:
declarations and disclosures of pecuniary interest and benefits
delegations that do not involve entering into agreements or arrangements that bind the organisation.
attendance and leave records
signed codes of conduct and oaths of allegiance
travel expenses
expenses returns and fees.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011 for most records.

List.Item: Queensland retains for between 7 and 10 years.
South Australia retains registers of interests for 6 years last entry
Tasmania retains for 5 years.
Western Australia retains for 7 years

Justification.Paragraph: Justification/Remarks: No change except for removal of requirement that where no summary record exists, declarations and disclosures of pecuniary interest and benefits are required as State archives. Entry 8.1 does require summary records as State archives.

Class.LinkedTo: 13.4.2 (B) - removal of requirement that where no summary record exists, declarations and disclosures of pecuniary interest and benefits are required as State archives
13.2.3 - change from 7 years after expiry of delegation to 10 years after term of office ceases

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to councillor representation on external committees or organisations. Records include nominations and appointment, minutes, agendas etc.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Queensland.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the routine management of Councillors. Includes:
submissions and determinations of categories and amounts of fees to be paid to councillors and Mayors received from remuneration tribunals
visits made by councillors to other organisations (accepted and declined)
arrangements for travel, training courses, workshops, seminars or conferences
declined requests for councillor representation on external committees or organisations
the election of Lord Mayor, Mayor or deputy mayor by Councillors.
transcripts of addresses, speeches or papers delivered by Councillors at routine occasions
background research, drafts, and audio visual recordings of all speeches
career summaries and information.

List.Item: Consistent with Queensland for declined requests for representation
Tasmania and Western Australia retain for 2 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Justification/Remarks: No change for drafting and recording of speeches or administrative arrangements for travel or workshops etc.

Previously:
Records of visits made by Councillors were retained for 6 years
determinations of categories and amounts of fees to be paid to councillors and Mayors received from the Local Government Remuneration Tribunal for 3 years
declined invitations, arrangements for travel, elections of Mayor, routine speeches, for 2 years.
This has been changed to administrative or reference use to streamline.

The requirement to retain career summaries of Councillors as State archives has been removed as entry 8.1 already requires summary records of disclosures of interests, the dismissal, censure and/or suspension of individual councillors, allegations of fraud, corruption or misconduct made against individual councillors, transcripts of final versions of addresses, speeches or papers delivered by councillors at significant occasions or public events as State archives.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activity of regulating and approving applications for the development, use, subdivision or classification of land or premises and related building and construction works.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to the development of building codes or standards

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Summary records or registers of building and development applications and consents. Includes:
development and building applications and consents
complying developments
subdivisions.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 2 Records are essential for the establishment and protection of fundamental rights and entitlements of individuals and groups within the community.
Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change. These registers provide a picture of land use and buildings in the State over time.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to approved, refused and lapsed applications for development or works on land, buildings or sites, including subdivisions, that:
set a precedent
are a recipient of State, national or international architectural or design awards
are an important local or regional landmark (this does not apply to entire local government areas)
are heritage listed or listed on Local Environment Plans (LEP) or Regional Environment Plans (REP)
represent the organisation's planning policy or the types of suburban, urban and commercial landscape within the locality
use materials in a unique or innovative way
are examples of unique and historic land use patterns
are approved by the Minister, including state significant developments
provide special zoning information unavailable from other sources
are dealt with by Joint Regional Planning Panels.

Records include:
applications and supporting documentation (plans, drawings, specifications etc.)
correspondence and notes of advice or meetings/conferences in relation to the application
required reports, impacts statements, management plans etc
decisions, notices and orders (including appeal processes)
notifications, submissions, objections or reports of community consultation
archival recordings of demolition
associated certificates.

Note: as the consent authority Councils should ensure they retain a record of development consents including documents from the Planning Portal and the Land and Environment Court that can be transferred as State archives when no longer required for business or reference purposes.

Justification.Paragraph: Basis for determination
Building the archives policy: Objective 4 Records relate to places of significance to the broader community and the State of NSW.
Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011

Justification/Remarks: No changes except:
certificates required as part of the consent and approval changed from retain a minimum of 10 years after action completed to State archives at request of councils
addition of note relating to the Planning Portal and the Land and Environment Court
Removal of note that architectural models could warrant retention as State archives at the request of MHNSW during the review. MHNSW’s experience is models submitted to Councils as part of a development application do not warrant retention as State archives.

December Board meeting: The Board requested that the word ‘prestigious’ be removed from the second dot point, listed on Local Environment Plans (LEP) or Regional Environment Plans (REP) be added to 4th dot point and controversial applications be removed as a criteria.

Class.LinkedTo: 7.2.1 - no change except for addition of note re the Planning Portal, the Land and Environment Court and that this entry does not apply to an entire Council area
18.8.1 - change of criteria from major to existing criteria for development consents.
7.2.7 - change from 10 years after action completed to required as State archives for certificates that are issued as part of the approval process and where criteria is met.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to approved applications for major developments or works on land, buildings, or sites that are not significant. Includes large structures, whole buildings or major additions to a site or structure etc. Records include:
applications and supporting documentation (plans, drawings, specifications etc.)
correspondence and notes of advice or meetings/conferences in relation to the application
required reports, impacts statements, management plans etc
decisions, notices and orders (including appeal processes)
notifications, submissions, objections or reports of community consultation
associated certificates.
Note: see entry above for definitions of significance.

List.Item: Consistent with Victoria and Queensland.
South Australia retains until building demolished, or for single dwellings for 10 years after action completed or all conditions cease to apply.
Tasmania retains until removed or demolished.
WA retains for 30 years after action completed.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change for application records. For associated certificates change from 10 years after action completed to 10 years after action completed or until structure is removed.

Class.LinkedTo: 7.2.2 - no change except for addition of note re the Planning Portal and Land and Environment Court
7.2.7 - change from 10 years after action completed to 10 years after structure is demolished or removed for certificates that are issued as part of the approval process.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to approved applications for subdivisions that are not significant. Includes:
applications
plans
associated correspondence
statements of compliance
associated certificates.
Note: see entry above for definitions of significance.

List.Item: South Australia retains for 60 years.
Western Australia for 30 years.
Victoria retains for 10 years after certification of the plan of subdivision.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: no change. Subdivision plans are lodged with Land Registry Services and are required as State archives under their disposal authority.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to approved applications for temporary structures and minor developments or works on land, buildings or sites where development consent is required, e.g. aerials, antennas, carports, fences, masts, private garages, pergolas, tennis courts, patios, retaining walls, tents, stages, stalls etc.
Note: this entry also covers legacy applications for developments that are now considered as exempt or complying applications.

List.Item: Queensland retains until removed or demolished.
South Australia & Tasmania retains non-habitable buildings or structures e.g. carports, sheds, fences, masts, retaining walls, swimming pools, bushfire shelters for 10 years after action completed.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: Disposal trigger changed from issue of final certification to action completed at request of councils.

Class.LinkedTo: 7.2.3 - trigger changed from issue of final certification to approval or action completed & addition of note re legacy records of applications now considered exempt or complying
7.2.4 - trigger changed to approval or action completed. removal of trigger relating to demolition of structure
walls, retaining or freestanding - temporary/minor development

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to refused, withdrawn, cancelled or abandoned development applications that do not relate to significant properties

List.Item: Queensland retains for 2 years after lapsing or 5 years if approved then lapse
Western Australia retains subdivisions for 7 years.
Victoria retains for 7 years after final action.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011 for development applications that are not heritage listed or significant that are refused, withdrawn or cancelled.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to lapsed development consents that do not relate to significant properties.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011

TermDescription.Paragraph: Activities associated with the conduct of elections, referenda or polls.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to the election of the Lord Mayor, Mayor or deputy mayor by Councillors.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Key records of elections. Includes:
electoral rolls
declaration of results.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 1 Records provide evidence of authority to perform duties and functions.
Benchmark: Consistent with South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change.

The Electoral Commission (NSWEC) has advised that from 2017 councils must engage either the NSWEC or an electoral services provider to conduct local government elections of councillors, popularly elected mayors, polls and referenda.

Councils that have engaged NSWEC to administer their elections will not have many of the records specified here. Rather, NSWEC will retain the records in accordance with FA0357 and the Local Government (General) Regulation 2021 (NSW) (LG Regulation). FA357 requires rolls as State archives.
This entry covers elections that were conducted by councils.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the reporting of election results to the relevant authority, e.g. the NSW Electoral Commission.

Disposal.DisposalTrigger: date of election to which the records relate

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the conduct of elections. Records include:
voters' and electoral lists
notices of appointment, candidature, failure to vote
candidate information sheets
returning officers correspondence and accommodation arrangements
polling station arrangements
appeals regarding rolls, including enrolment claims and objections
requests for recount
objections
notifications of civic office vacancies
applications to dispense with a by-election where casual vacancies occur in civic offices, including determinations of applications.

List.Item: Tasmania retains for 7 years and electoral rolls until superseded.
Western Australia retains for between 2 years and 4 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the preparation for elections. Records include:
ballot papers
applications for enrolment
records relating to the printing of ballots
postal votes
pre-poll votes
statistical information sheets from nomination papers.
Note: the disposal of these records is currently regulated by the Local Government Regulation section 391 (4) and (5).

CustomAction.Paragraph: Retain in accordance with the Local Government Regulation, then destroy

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Tasmania. Western Australia retains for 4 years.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

In general, councils must engage either the NSWEC or an electoral services provider to conduct local government elections of councillors, popularly elected mayors, polls and referenda. Councils that have engaged NSWEC to administer their elections will not have many of the records specified in under 10.0. Rather, NSWEC will retain the records and dispose of them in accordance with FA0357 and the Local Government (General) Regulation 2021 (NSW) (LG Regulation). The election manager of an electoral services provider is required to ensure election materials are kept secure for the periods of time specified in s 391(4) of the LG Regulation.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities related to preventing loss and minimising threats to life, property and the natural environment, from fire and other emergency situations.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to the appointment of emergency personnel.
for records of committees (including State, District and Local Emergency Management Committees).
for records of conferences relating to emergency prevention and response.
for records relating to the handling of complaints concerning existing and potential hazards.
for records relating to the acquisition, disposal and maintenance of emergency and fire fighting equipment.
for records relating to the design, construction, maintenance and security of emergency management centres and bushfire control centres.
for records of policy, procedures and standards relating to emergency prevention and response.
for records relating to audits of disaster preparedness.
for records of agreements relating to emergency prevention and response.
for records of tenders relating to emergency prevention and response.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the establishment and disbandment of rural fire brigades by the organisation, e.g. notices of establishment, disbandment, appeals and Ministerial determinations.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 2 Records provide evidence of the identity of individuals and groups, their right to participate in the affairs of the State and make claim to entitlements and protection provided by the State.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011. Consistent with equivalent records for the Rural Fire Service.
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Reports compiled or commissioned by the organisation into emergencies, bushfires and incidents where the organisation applies to the State Government for special assistance or where there was loss of life or extensive damage to multiple properties or the environment. Includes, research, summaries of consultation, final versions.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 5 Records document significant impacts of government decisions on the environment.
Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria and South Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011

Justification/Remarks: No change. The Rural Fire Service, State Emergency Services and Fire and Rescue are the lead agencies in responding to fires and other emergencies. The reports of the management of emergencies within a local government area are retained as State archives in their retention and disposal authorities. This entry will capture records of incidents such as the catastrophic bushfires that affected the Blue Mountains.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the management of emergencies that involve loss of life or extensive damage to multiple properties or the environment. Records include:
details of works carried out and assistance rendered, etc.
debriefs and reports
advice and warnings to the public.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria. Queensland retains for 20 years.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011

Justification/Remarks: No change. Records provide evidence of the organisation's response to emergencies and disasters, and are required for planning for future emergencies and in case legal or other issues arise. Key information concerning major disasters and emergencies is contained in reports, which will be retained as State archives (see entry 11.3).

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to emergencies involving minor injuries and damage to property and the environment. Records include:
details of works carried out and assistance rendered, etc.
debriefs and reports.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Victoria and Tasmania. South Australia retains for 6 years.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to liaison with emergency services providers and preparations for emergencies. Includes:

the issue or receipt of notices concerning emergency situations and emergency prevention activities such as danger periods, fire bans, fire hazard reduction activities etc.

List.Item: Consistent with Tasmania.
Queensland retains for between 5 and 10 years.
South Australia retains for 6 years after superseded.

Justification.Paragraph: Justification/Remarks: No change except for increase from 5 to 10 years for notices concerning emergency situations and emergency prevention activities such as danger periods, fire bans, fire hazard reduction activities at request of the Rural Fire Service.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities of applying for and receiving grants, subsidies and rebates. Includes grants applied for and/or received by the organisation and grants made by the organisation to other bodies or individuals.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Summary records of grants and subsidies received or disbursed by the organisation.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 5 Records document the impact of government activities on the community.
Benchmark: Consistent with Queensland, South Australia, WA and Tasmania.

Justification/Remarks: No change. During the review MHNSW queried the requirement to retain summary records of grants as significant programs involving grants will be retained as State archives under entry 5.1.

SRNSW noted that this is an existing requirement and corruption around grants has been highlighted as an issue by ICAC and the Audit Office of NSW. This is yearly reporting at a high level and should not be too onerous. In many cases these records are contained within Annual Reports or reports to the Minister.

Class.LinkedTo: 15.7.1 - no change except for addition of note that records are not required as State archives if information is duplicated in annual reports etc

Class.LinkedTo: 8.11.1 - change from 10 years after action completed to 7 years after repayments are finalised for loans and mortgages provided to the community.

Justification/Remarks: Previously applications which led to the establishment of new and significant programs, events or outcomes were required as State archives. This requirement has been removed as applications tend to be routine records. The reports of any significant programs established by a grant will be retained as State archives under entry 5.1.
The disposal action for grants that do not lead to new and significant programs has been changed to include the proviso that terms and conditions are met.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities involved in providing library and public information access services.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to the establishment, negotiation, maintenance and review of agreements for the operation of library and information services

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the control of the library collection and provision of library services. Includes:
control and tracking records, catalogues, shelf listing, discard lists, accession lists, borrowing records, overdues etc.
membership applications, parental/guardian permissions and summary records of borrowers
library research services and enquiries
outreach activities, including book clubs and book readings, children's activities, holiday programs, online services and social networking, e.g. blogs.

List.Item: Victoria retains for between 1 and 2 years or until administrative use ceases
Tasmania retains for 2 years.
Queensland retains records of collection control until superseded, temporary loans for 5 years, activities for 2 years, library membership for 2 years.
South Australia retains for between 2 and 6 years.
Tasmania retains for 2 years.
Western Australia retains for between reference use and 7 years.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: No change for control of the library collection and library membership.
Justification/Remarks: Previously records were retained for between 1 year and 5 years. Changed to administrative or reference use to streamline the authority.

Class.LinkedTo: 3.8.4 - change from 2 years to administrative or reference use
3.8.7 - change from 1 year to administrative or reference use
3.8.3 - change from 5 years to administrative or reference use

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records relating to the acquisition of items or information resources through donation or permanent loan, including gifts, e.g. manuscripts, private records collections, publications, etc. Records include conditions for library donations.
Note: private records and objects held in local studies collections are not State records.

Disposal.DisposalTrigger: donation is received and finalised, or until terms have been fulfilled, whichever is later

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Western Australia and Tasmania. South Australia retains for 6 years. Victoria retains until administrative use has concluded.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Records of photocopying and reproduction declarations.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Queensland. South Australia retains for 6 years, Western Australia for 2 years.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.

Justification/Remarks: No change. The Copyright Act (Cth) requires that declarations submitted as part of a document delivery request are retained for at least four years after making the reproduction of the material to which the declaration relates.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities associated with acquiring, managing, designing and constructing parks, reserves and open spaces, either owned, controlled or managed by the organisation.
Includes landscaping of parks, reserves, roadsides, gardens and playing fields and provision of horticultural services to the community.

Note: Local government agencies responsible for the management of Crown reserves, commons and land that is currently or may potentially be the subject of a claim under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983 should ensure records providing evidence of ownership, control and usage of the relevant parcel are retained and not destroyed until a claim has been granted over that parcel of land.

These records could include planning documents or decisions concerning proposed or approved use of the land, surveys, agreements, memorandums, consents and tenure arrangements regarding the following land matters – acquisition, transfers, boundaries, usage, rights of way and easements, leases or licences for any uses/purposes, land/resource management and management of parks and reserves.
Please note that the making of a claim which is unsuccessful does not preclude the making of further claims over the same areas of land under the Act.

SeeReference.SeeText: for significant tree and plant inventories, etc. outside of Council parks and reserves
for permits to use parks, reserves and beaches
for records relating to the issue of notices, orders, infringements and penalty notices for breaches of road regulations.
for records relating to claims arising out of tree damage.
for records relating to the management of Trusts established to manage and maintain reserves including Crown land.
for records relating to the design and construction of structures within parks and reserves.
for project management records
for records relating to tenancy agreements for caravan park residents

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Key records relating to the management of parks and reserves. Includes:
the acquisition and disposal of land for the purpose of public recreation and open space, e.g. investigations, images, photographs, maps etc.
the design, landscaping, construction, major renovation, remodelling or restoration of parks and reserves that are an important local landmark
the establishment, negotiation, maintenance and review of agreements with private landholders to maintain a section of their holding as a conservation reserve
the naming and renaming of parks, reserves and topographical features
the management of heritage listed, protected or unique trees and plants in the parks, reserves, gardens, and on roadsides.

Records include: agreements, investigations into acquisition and disposal, plans, designs, photographs, suggestions and objections to naming, planting information, tree condition reports, planting information, including location details, number planted and historical information, and photographs.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the archives policy: Objective 4 Records relate to places of significance to the broader community and the State of NSW.
Benchmark: Consistent with Queensland, WA, Tasmania & South Australia.
Precedent: Confirms existing authorised decision.
Justification/Remarks: no change.

Class.LinkedTo: 21.3.1 - no change for parks and reserves

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Operational records of the management of parks and reserves. Includes:
agreements with private landholders to maintain a section of their holding as a conservation reserve which do not proceed
the maintenance and management of trees and plants in parklands, gardens, roadsides and road reserves which are not heritage listed, protected or unique
design and landscaping of playing fields
the design, landscaping of parks and reserves that are not an important local landmark
minor works for all parks and reserves
complaints from members of the public
planting information, including location details.
projects or proposals not proceeded with.

List.Item: Consistent with WA.

Tasmania retains records relating to the design and construction of parks and reserves that have no significance beyond their use as open spaces for 25 years after sale of property, and landscaping of playing grounds etc or 5 years after work superseded

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change except retention period for agreements that do not proceed reduced from 10 years to 7 years to simplify disposal.

Class.LinkedTo: 21.3.2 - change of trigger from superseded to action completed

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Facilitative records. Includes:
provision of horticultural services and advice
provision of free trees and street trees and materials
administrative records relating to the naming of parks and reserves
service coordination, operation schedules, daily operations, bookings etc. for services provided in parks and reserves by or on behalf of the organisation, e.g. caravan parks, golf courses, camping grounds, etc.

List.Item: Queensland retains service coordination records for 3 years.
Consistent with Tasmania and Western Australia.

Justification.Paragraph: Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011 for routine records of parks.
Justification/Remarks: Retention period for provision of advice and free trees reduced from 5 to 2 years to streamline the authority.

TermDescription.Paragraph: The activities associated with the determination, administration, review and enforcement of property valuations and property rates. Includes managing the numbering and history of a property.

SeeReference.SeeText: for records relating to authorisations for direct debit for payments of rates, powers of attorney etc
for records relating to challenges to or appeals against a property's classification status for rating purposes that set a precedent.
for records relating to policies to determine rating status and the classification of land

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Registers or equivalent summary records of rateable property which show details of the property and owners/ratepayers, e.g. rate books, assessment books (rate books which show minimal details such as the amount of rates paid with no property details are not required as State archives - see entries below).

Justification.Paragraph: Building the Archives: Objective 2 Records provide evidence of the identity of individuals, their right to participate in the affairs of the State and make claim to entitlements and protection provided by the State.
Benchmark: Consistent with Tasmania, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Valuation books compiled by the organisation prior to the Valuation of Land Act applying in the area, e.g. Valuation Books issued by the Valuer - General.
Note: see the Notes section of the Valuation of Land Act for details of when the Act applied to each Council area.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the Archives: Objective 2 Records provide evidence of the identity of individuals, their right to participate in the affairs of the State and make claim to entitlements and protection provided by the State.
Benchmark: Consistent with South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria, Western Australia and Queensland
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change

ClassDescription.Paragraph: Summary records relating to the recognition of a unique property identification number, including street numbering and re-numbering.

Justification.Paragraph: Building the Archives: Objective 2 Records document the administration of interests in land / real property.
Benchmark: Consistent with Tasmania, Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia.

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Records relating to the payment and non-payment of rates. Includes:
rate notices issued and payments received

debt recovery transactions including transfer or sale of land to recover debts and ex-gratia payments
properties where owners are unknown
outstanding rates certificates and notifications
notices issued to ratepayers in relation to valuations, rates and charges, rate remissions, classification of land, etc.
appeals against a property's classification status for rating purposes
objections against the inclusion of land owned or managed by a public organisation in the rates rebate list.

Justification.Paragraph: Benchmark: Consistent with Tasmania and Western Australia.
Precedent: Confirms Board decision of 2011.
Justification/Remarks: No change.

Records relating to managing applications for rate rebates, reductions, payment plans etc. Includes:
approval for rate rebates, reductions or waivers
requests for exemptions or postponements of rates

Records include:
applications

ClassDescription.Paragraph:
Facilitative records relating to rate collection, payment and system updates. Includes:
